title: Turtle Soup
statement: A man walks into a restaurant and orders turtle soup. He takes one sip, asks the waiter 'Is this really turtle soup?', and the waiter confirms it is. The man kills himself that night. Why?

questions.text: Is the reason for the man's death related to the restaurant visit?
Did the man come to the restaurant for a specific purpose?
Is the specific dish — turtle soup — important to the story?
Was the man's death caused by romantic problems?
Was the man's death caused by financial problems?
Was the man suffering from a terminal illness?
Was the soup poisoned or contaminated?
Did the waiter do or say something that upset the man?
Is the location of the restaurant significant?
Is the time of day important?
Was the taste of the soup important?
Had the man eaten turtle soup before?
Was the man a food critic or inspector?
Did the man know the waiter personally?
Was the man expecting the turtle soup to taste differently?
Was the man comparing the taste to a past experience?
Did the man stop eating after one sip because the soup tasted bad?
Was the "turtle soup" the man ate in the past actually not turtle soup?
Was the man deceived about what he ate in the past?
Did the man visit the restaurant specifically to test what real turtle soup tastes like?
Did confirming it was real turtle soup make things worse for the man?
Was the man in a dangerous or life-threatening situation in the past?
Was the true ingredient of the past "soup" something morally unacceptable?
Would the man have refused to eat the soup if he had known the truth?
Were the people who lied to him trying to help him survive?
Did the man commit a crime in his past?
Was the man shipwrecked?
Did the man's food run out during the survival situation?
Did someone die during the survival situation?
Was the "soup" on the island made from the dead person's body?
Was the "soup" made from human flesh?
Did the man realize at the restaurant that he had eaten human flesh in the past?
Were the man's companions on the island the ones who deceived him?
Was the companion who died murdered by the other survivors?
Did the man kill himself because of the horror of what he had unknowingly eaten?
Was the method of suicide important?
Was the man alone when he entered the restaurant?
Was the man a sailor or someone who travels by sea?
Did the man have companions in his past experience?
Did the man receive bad news at the restaurant (e.g., a phone call)?
Was the past event related to war or military service?
Is the key to the mystery something the man remembered or realized?
Was the food simply a different type of animal meat?
